results.title: La Grande Lessive! = The Big Wash!
results.brief_description:
Apalled to see how sleepy and apathetic his students have become, headmaster Saint-Just enrolls the help of a gym teacher and an inventor to sabotage all the TV antennas of Paris. The police is soon called to solve the mystery as the professor and his crew slowly move towards their ultimate goal of spraying the transmitter atop the Eiffel tower. Best print: X0109 ; 2nd best: X0032.

Credits: Producer, Georges Cheyko ; director, Jean-Pierre Mocky ; writers, Jean-Pierre Mocky, Claude Pennec, Alain Moury ; photography, Marcel Weiss ; music, Francois de Roubaix ; editor, Marguerite Renoir ; art direction, Pierre Tyberghien.
Cast: Bourvil, Francis Blanche, Roland Dubillard, Jean Poiret, Jean Tissier, Michel Lonsdale, Karin Balm.

results.title: L'amour Par Terre = Love on the Ground
results.brief_description:
Playwright Clement Roquemaure attends the private performance of one of his plays. He then invites the actresses, Charlotte and Emily, to act in a yet to be completed play in his appartment and for a selected audience. A magician named Paul is Clement’s current live-in lover. After the actresses arrive, they find themselves influenced by Paul’s magic and start to see their future, while the story they are enacting stays fairly close to Clement’s own life.

Credits: Producer, Martine Marignac ; director, Jacques Rivette ; writers, Jacques Rivette, Marilu Parolini, Pascal Bonitzer, Suzanne Schiffman ; photography, William Lubtchansky, Caroline Champetier ; editor, Nicole Lubtchansky ; sound, Pierre Gamet.
Cast: Geraldine Chaplin, Jane Birkin, Andre Dussolier, Jean-Pierre Kalfon, Facundo Bo, Laszlo Szabo.

results.title: Les Belles de Nuit = Beauties of the Night
results.brief_description:
Claude, an impoverished music teacher, lives a life of boredom in a small provincial town. His lovely young neighbour seems smitten, but he has little time for her. Each sound he hears or every person he meets begets a new fancy. He dreams himself a conquering hero, a musketeer, or a soldier of the French Revolution, but always the conquerer of delicious women. The conflict between waking and dream worlds leads to amusing, strange, even fantastic situations. Which world will prevail?

Credits: Producer, Leon Carre ; director, Rene Clair ; writer, Rene Clair, Pierre Barrillet, Jean-Pierre Gredy ; photography, Armand Thirard ; music, Georges van Parys ; art direction, Leon Barsacq ; costumes, Rosine Delamare ; assistant director, Mic
Cast: Gerard Philipe, Gina Lollobrigida, Jean Paredes, Martine carol, Raymond Bussieres, Magali de Vendeuil, Bernard Lajarrigue, Marylin Bufferd, Pierre Palau, Jane Pierson.

results.title: Le Dernier Milliardaire = the Last Millionaire
results.brief_description:
Le Dernier Milliardaire’ tells the story of a small mythical European country, Casinario, suddenly subjected to the whims of a mad dictator. Tobis Klangfilm refused to bankroll the project on political grounds, worried it could be considered a commentary on Hitler’s recent seizure of power in Germany. (Clair’s script also contained some fairly overt parodic references to Mussolini.) And so the (by now financially ailing) Pathe-Natan company had the bad fortune to produce what most observers consider the one complete failure among all of Clair’s works, a film scorned by audiences and critics alike as unfunny, tasteless, and cinematographically inept, although it is a sheer delight today. Unnerved by this commercial disaster, Clair left France for an artistic exile in England and, during the war years, the United States. It would be thirteen eventful years before his return to the French cinema, as an old master in the postwar ‘Tradition de Qualite’. Reference: Alan Williams. “Republic of Images: a history of French filmmaking”. Harvard University Press, 1992.

Credits: Director, Rene Clair ; writer, Rene Clair ; photography, Rudolph Mate, Louis Nee ; music, Maurice Jaubert ; art direction, Lucien Aguettand, Lucien Carre.
Cast: Max Dearly, Renee Saint-Cyr, Marthe Mellot, Jose Noguero, Charles Redgie, Jean Sinoel, Raymond Cordy, Christian Argentin, Marcel Carpentier.

results.title: Sans Mobile Apparent = No Apparent Motive
results.brief_description:
It all starts with the bold murder of a well-heeled Frenchman. Commissaire Carella assigned to the case is most puzzled for there seems to be no motive. Then an old man and an astrologer are killed in exactly the same way, leaving the detective to figure out how the three disparate victims are linked. All he has to go on is a mysterious diary given to him by the step daughter of the first victim and containing a list of the man’s lovers.

Credits: Producers, Jacques-Eric Strauss ; director, Philippe Labro ; writers, Philippe Labro, Jacques Lanzmann ; photography, Jean Penzer ; music, Ennio Morricone.
Cast: Jean-Louis Trintignant, Dominique Sanda, Sacha Distel, Carla Gravina, Erich Segal, Gilles Segal, Laura Antonelli, Paul Crauchet, Stephane Audran, Jean-Pierre Marielle.

results.title: Le Territoire des Autres = the Territory of Others
results.creator_credit: Francois Bel, Gerard Vienne and Michel Fano
results.brief_description:
Filmed around the world, this documentary is a patient observation of animals in their natural habitat. It is also a plea in favour of conservation and the creation of animal sanctuaries as the creatures of nature face the biggest enemy in humans who pollute and show callous disregard for the sanctity of wildlife and conservation. Awards: Grand Prix de la Commission Superieure Technique, Cannes 1970.

Credits: Directors, Michel Fano, Gerard Vienne, Francois Bel ; photography, Jacqueline Lecompte.

results.title: La Chinoise = the Chinese Girl
results.brief_description:
Veronique is a philosophy student. She is also the leader of a small group of friends who are interested in Marxist ideas. She lives in an apartment lined with shelves full of little red books. The group is made up of Guillaume, actor, Henri, student, Kirilov, a painter and Yvonne, prostitute. They are so taken by the external trappings of their cause — the posters, the Little Red Books, the by-rote chantings — that they seem not to grasp the true meaning of their political persuasion. Nor do they give any thought to the long-range ramifications of their terrorist activities. One day, Veronique proposes to assassinate a famous person. ‘La Chinoise’ is a montage film. Godard filmed each sequence as an autonomous piece, in no particular order. There was no preset idea about the chronology nor the ending. Some exterior scenes were shot on the Nanterre University Campus which was to become the starting point of the May 68 student movement.

Credits: Producer, Philippe Dussart ; director, Jean-Luc Godard ; writer, Jean-Luc Godard ; photography, Raoul Coutard.
Cast: Anne Wiazemsky, Jean-Pierre Leaud, Juliet Berto, Michel Semeniako, Lex de Brujn, Omar Diop, Francis Jeanson.

results.title: Mille Sept Cent Quatre Vingt Neuf = 1789
results.creator_credit: Arianne Mnouchkine, Alexandre Mnouchkine and Georges Dancigers
results.brief_description:
This film records a production of the historical play ‘1789’, in which the Theatre du Soleil re-enacts the French Revolution and its aftermath. It shows how the Revolution served only to replace one set of rulers (the aristocrats and nobles) with another (the rich), an analysis which is clearly influenced by Marxist thinking. Filmed in June 1973 during 13 shows presented on the stage of ‘La Cartoucherie de Vincennes’. Best print: X0131.

Credits: Producers, Georges Dancigers, Alexandre Mnouchkine ; director, Arianne Mnouchkine ; writer, Ariane Mnouchkine ; photography, Jean-Paul Meurisse, Michel Lebon, Eduardo Serra, Bernard Zitzerman.
Cast: Philippe Caubere, Mario Gonzales, Genevieve Penchenat, Jean-Claude Penchenat.

results.title: La Femme de Ma Vie = Woman in My Life
results.brief_description:
Simon is a virtuoso violonist and an alcoholic. One night, he collapses during a live-to-air TV concert. Following the incident, he is submerged with shame and avoids his wife, Laura. Laura is the women to whom Simon owes his career ever since she set up and managed the orcherstra Simon plays in. In the depth of his crisis, Simon meets Bernard who has been through the same experiences. As Bernard undertakes to heal Simon he unwittingly becomes Laura’s rival who cannot accept to see Simon receiving assistance from anybody but her. Awards: French Academy of Cinema (Cesar) - Best New Director of a Feature Film 1987.

Credits: Producer, Yannick Bernard ; director, Regis Wargnier ; writers, Catherine Cohen, Alain Le Henry, Regis Wargnier, Alain Wermus ; photography, Francois Catonne ; music, Romano Musumura.
Cast: Christophe Malavoy, Jane Birkin, Jean-Louis Trintignant, Beatrice Agenin, Elsa Lunghini, Florent Pagny, Dominique Blanc, Didier Sandre, Andrzej Seweryn.

results.title: La Belle Equipe = They Were Five
results.brief_description:
The fortune of five unemployed labourers take a radical turn for the better when they jointly win a 100,000 francs lottery prize. Jean, the self-appointed leader of the bunch, suggests they invest their money in a ‘guinguette’ (country pub cum outdoor entertainment) on the river Marne. Their dreams of instant success are dashed when Gina, Charles’ girlfriend, shows up demanding her portion of the winnings, then plots the destruction of Jean because he rebuffed her. The film was filmed with two endings. At the first release, the tragic ending chosen by Duvivier was a total flop. After 6 weeks, the film was withdrawn and re-released with a happy ending version. A very beautiful film which will be remembered as one of Duvivier’s finest. It is sensitive without sentimentality, original without effort, populist without vulgarity ; it starts with gaiety and we all feel gay. It ends tragically and our hearts rend. Simple people for a simple story, but with an added dimension of deep tragic poetry, for it shows how destiny can change and look like luck at first, then become fatality.” Source: L’Avant-Scene du Cinema, March 1996.

Credits: Producer, Arys Nissotti ; director, Julien Duvivier ; writer, Julien Duvivier, Charles Spaak ; photography, Jules Kruger, Marc Fossard ; music, Maurice Yvain ; art direction, Jacques Krauss.
Cast: Jean Gabin, Charles Vanel, Raymond Aimos, Charles Dorat, Viviane Romance, Raphael Medina, Fernand Charpin, Raymond Cordy, Charles Granval.
